ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: Any recommended reading on combining novelty search and competitive coevolution?
ygData.msgSnippet: Stephane, Nevermind about my question, I just noticed in the paper where you said that NCD was too slow for your application. Very useful technique regardless.

Stephane,

Nevermind about my question, I just noticed in the paper where y=
ou said that
NCD was too slow for your application. Very useful technique r=
egardless.


-Drew

dre=
w.kirkpatrick@...> wrote:

> Stephane,
>
> Thanks for passing along y=
our papers, they were very interesting reads and
> such an approach could w=
ork well for my particular need.
>
> I'm curious as to why you chose to use=
 hamming distance as opposed to
> normalized compression distance? I would =
imagine that if you have strings of
> equal length for comparison, then ham=
ming distance would be considerably
> faster, but you can only use it in ca=
ses where the strings are of equal
> length, correct?
>
> -Drew

om> wrote:

>>

>> Hi Ken,
>>
>> just a point concerning behavior charac=
terization. You can actually use
>> raw inputs and raw outputs. Your robot =
will probably have sensors to detect
>> collision with a wall -- a bumper f=
or instance -- at least if you want it to
>> react to such a situation. "St=
alled against a wall" can then easily be
>> detected relative to "going for=
ward" because of the value of such a sensor
>> and then considered as diffe=
rent.
>>
>> We have add very good results with novelty search or behavioral=
 diversity
>> while using a discretized version of the stream of inputs and=
 outputs
>> (simply 0 if below min+range/2 and 1 otherwise) and the hamming=
 distance to
>> compute behavioral distances. See for instance:
>>
>> * Don=
cieux, S. and Mouret, J.-B. (2010). Behavioral diversity measures for
>> Ev=
olutionary Robotics. IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation, 2010 (CEC
>=
> 2010).
>>
>> http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evorob_db/moin.wsgi/Behavioraldive=
rsitymeasuresforEvolutionaryRobotics
>> * T. Pinville, S. Koos, J.-B. Moure=
t , S. Doncieux (2011). How to Promote
>> Generalisation in Evolutionary Ro=
botics: the ProGAb Approach. GECCO 2011
>>
>> http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evo=
rob_db/moin.wsgi/HowToPromoteGeneralisationInErProGAb
>>
>> It is quite sur=
prising how efficient it can be, but results are here. A
>> paper of us sho=
uld appear soon in Evolutionary Computation in which we
>> performed intens=
ive comparisons.
>>
>> It is anyway not clear yet whether it scales well or=
 not with a bigger set
>> inputs/outputs, but we have noticed good results =
with this behavior
>> characterization on problems with up to 16 sensors+ef=
fectors.
>>
>> stephane
>>
>>
>> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Ken" <kstanl=
ey@...> wrote:
>> >
>> >
>> >
>> > Hi Drew, I understand the basic idea you=
 have. It does sound like you
>> have a workable idea for integrating novel=
ty search into competitive
>> coevolution. Of course, I'd be particularly c=
areful on the way behavior is
>> measured because it is the key to identify=
ing novelty. One tip is to make
>> sure you don't only include raw outputs =
or raw inputs as part of the
>> behavior characterization, because what mat=
ters most is what an agent
>> actually does, as opposed to what it wants to=
 do. For example, if an agent
>> spend 100 timesteps trying to run through =
a wall, we would want to
>> characterize its behavior as being stalled rath=
er than as moving forward.
>> >
>> > Also, one of the big challenges in com=
petitive coevolution (and alife in
>> general) is to create a domain that i=
s open-ended enough to support
>> something interesting arising. The robot =
duel was my attempt to do that, but
>> perhaps it could be enhanced to supp=
ort more open-endedness, though I don't
>> know how off-hand. But the risk =
you always have in these domains is that
>> even if you have a fantastic al=
gorithmic setup that in principle could
>> discover amazing behaviors, it i=
s always possible that the domain itself
>> only supports a limited range o=
f strategies. For example, it is hard to
>> imagine strategies in the robot=
 duel that go very far beyond the one shown
>> here:
>> >
>> > http://www.c=
s.utexas.edu/users/nn/pages/research/robotmovies/clip8.gif
>> >
>> > In any=
 case, overall I think your idea can make a good experiment. You
>> mention=
 that you need to write something up for graduation - what degree are
>> yo=
u working on?
>> >
>> > ken
>> >

kpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@>

duel from

omplexi=EF=AC
>> cation".
>> > > Instead of categorizing the parasite behav=
ior, I was thinking break
>> out
>> > > meaningful classifications of senso=
r inputs. Classification of
>> behavior of

t's movement vector and speed (moving away,
>> > > towards, fast/slow, goin=
g after food, etc). Of course, this is a

>> > > environment.

ior of

vidual novelty
>> > > measurements are all added up at the end of the run, =
and divided by
>> the
>> > > number of class of input changes to normalize =
things.

>> > >
>> > > As far as maki=
ng it real "competitive coevolution", of course a record
>> of
>> > > who w=
on is essentially a fitness measure, so there'd have to be a
>> hybrid
>> >=
 > novelty/fitness in there somewhere, because measuring who won is not a
>=
> > > novelty measure.
>> > >
>> > > I still think novelty search brings a =
lot of benefits to the table. My
>> > > current spit-ball is that there is =
an added parameter for population
>> growth
>> > > allowance for the host g=
roup. Instead of a fitness function, a novelty
>> > > metric is used (assum=
ing one can be made, obviously that's tricky).
>> The host
>> > > populatio=
n remains the hosts until their population has grown the
>> specified
>> > =
> amount. I'm hoping that will encourage a nice broad range of
>> strategie=
s to
>> > > be evaluated. Once that max population % has been hit, a "catac=
lysmic
>> event"
>> > > occurs (cataclysm-neat? rapture-neat? Harold Campin=
g-neat?) to wipe
>> out the
>> > > extra population, and only the best perf=
orming hosts are kept, which
>> would
>> > > be how it integrates into the =
competition side of things. .
>> > >
>> > > Then the parasites and hosts fl=
ip. Essentially novelty is used to
>> explore
>> > > differing behaviors up=
 until the cataclysmic event, then performance
>> is used
>> > > to prune t=
he population back down, and give the "other team" their go.
>> > >
>> > > =
Not sure if there would be any benefit to such an approach, but if I
>> can=

>> > > figure out a means of quantifying the novelty, I'm gonna give it a
=
>> whirl.
>> > > Gotta write up something interesting to graduate I suppose=
.
>> > >

>> > >

rew

d up with a large modular NN, with each module being a novelty

riate NN module to use

farts.

I know, competitive coevolution and novelty search

omplication when combining both techniques is that the

=

s

at a checkers-playing agent
>> proceeds
>> > > > through
>> > > > > > depen=
ds on its opponent.

hen applying novelty search in a
>> noisy
>> > > > > > environment; its beh=
avior might then be probabilistic. You could
>> do

>> relate=
d to

velty search might

ch is very interesting though, and I

 follow up on it. I think it is particularly promising if done

 open-ended

is). However, in practice coevolution is

Stephane,<div><br></div><div>Nevermind about my question, I just noticed in=
 the paper where you said that NCD was too slow for your application. Very =
useful technique regardless.=A0</div><div><br></div><div><br></div><div>-Dr=
ew<br>

<br><div class=3D"gmail_quote">On Sat, Jun 11, 2011 at 4:57 PM, Dre=
w Kirkpatrick <span dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:drew.kirkpatrick@gmai=
l.com">drew.kirkpatrick@...</a>></span> wrote:<br><blockquote clas=
s=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc solid;pad=
ding-left:1ex;">

Stephane,<div><br></div><div>Thanks for passing along you=
r papers, they were very interesting reads and such an approach could work =
well for my particular need.=A0</div><div><br></div><div>I'm curious as=
 to why you chose to use hamming distance as opposed to normalized compress=
ion distance? I would imagine that if you have strings of equal length for =
comparison, then hamming distance would be considerably faster, but you can=
 only use it in cases where the strings are of equal length, correct?</div>=



<div><br></div><div>-Drew<div><div></div><div class=3D"h5"><br><br><div =
class=3D"gmail_quote">On Fri, Jun 10, 2011 at 4:29 AM, stephane.doncieux <s=
pan dir=3D"ltr"><<a href=3D"mailto:stephane.doncieux@..." target=
=3D"_blank">stephane.doncieux@...</a>></span> wrote:<br>


<blockq=
uote class=3D"gmail_quote" style=3D"margin:0 0 0 .8ex;border-left:1px #ccc =
solid;padding-left:1ex">













<div style=3D"background-color:#fff">=

<span>=A0</span>


<div>
  <div>


    <div>
      
      
      <p>Hi Ken=
,<br>
<br>
just a point concerning behavior characterization. You can actua=
lly use raw inputs and raw outputs. Your robot will probably have sensors t=
o detect collision with a wall -- a bumper for instance -- at least if you =
want it to react to such a situation. "Stalled against a wall" ca=
n then easily be detected relative to "going forward" because of =
the value of such a sensor and then considered as different. <br>



<br>
W=
e have add very good results with novelty search or behavioral diversity wh=
ile using a discretized version of the stream of inputs and outputs (simply=
 0 if below min+range/2 and 1 otherwise) and the hamming distance to comput=
e behavioral distances. See for instance:<br>



<br>
* Doncieux, S. and Mo=
uret, J.-B. (2010). Behavioral diversity measures for Evolutionary Robotics=
. IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation, 2010 (CEC 2010). <br>
<a href=
=3D"http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evorob_db/moin.wsgi/Behavioraldiversitymeasur=
esforEvolutionaryRobotics" target=3D"_blank">http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evor=
ob_db/moin.wsgi/BehavioraldiversitymeasuresforEvolutionaryRobotics</a><br>
=



* T. Pinville, S. Koos, J.-B. Mouret , S. Doncieux (2011). How to Promot=
e Generalisation in Evolutionary Robotics: the ProGAb Approach. GECCO 2011<=
br>
<a href=3D"http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evorob_db/moin.wsgi/HowToPromoteGe=
neralisationInErProGAb" target=3D"_blank">http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/evorob_=
db/moin.wsgi/HowToPromoteGeneralisationInErProGAb</a><br>
<br>
It is quite =
surprising how efficient it can be, but results are here. A paper of us sho=
uld appear soon in Evolutionary Computation in which we performed intensive=
 comparisons. <br>
<br>
It is anyway not clear yet whether it scales well o=
r not with a bigger set inputs/outputs, but we have noticed good results wi=
th this behavior characterization on problems with up to 16 sensors+effecto=
rs.<br>
<br>
stephane</p><div><div></div><div><br>
<br>
--- In <a href=3D"m=
ailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, &=
quot;Ken" <kstanley@...> wrote:<br>
><br>
> <br>
> <br>=

> Hi Drew, I understand the basic idea you have.  It does sound like yo=
u have a workable idea for integrating novelty search into competitive coev=
olution.  Of course, I'd be particularly careful on the way behavior is=
 measured because it is the key to identifying novelty.  One tip is to make=
 sure you don't only include raw outputs or raw inputs as part of the b=
ehavior characterization, because what matters most is what an agent actual=
ly does, as opposed to what it wants to do.  For example, if an agent spend=
 100 timesteps trying to run through a wall, we would want to characterize =
its behavior as being stalled rather than as moving forward.<br>



> <b=
r>
> Also, one of the big challenges in competitive coevolution (and ali=
fe in general) is to create a domain that is open-ended enough to support s=
omething interesting arising.  The robot duel was my attempt to do that, bu=
t perhaps it could be enhanced to support more open-endedness, though I don=
't know how off-hand.  But the risk you always have in these domains is=
 that even if you have a fantastic algorithmic setup that in principle coul=
d discover amazing behaviors, it is always possible that the domain itself =
only supports a limited range of strategies.  For example, it is hard to im=
agine strategies in the robot duel that go very far beyond the one shown he=
re: <br>



> <br>
> <a href=3D"http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/nn/pag=
es/research/robotmovies/clip8.gif" target=3D"_blank">http://www.cs.utexas.e=
du/users/nn/pages/research/robotmovies/clip8.gif</a>  <br>
> <br>
> I=
n any case, overall I think your idea can make a good experiment.  You ment=
ion that you need to write something up for graduation - what degree are yo=
u working on?<br>
> <br>
> ken<br>
> <br>
> --- In <a href=3D"m=
ailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com" target=3D"_blank">neat@yahoogroups.com</a>, D=

inputs. Classification of behavior of<br>

 it's movement vector and speed (moving away,<br>

st/slow, going after food, etc). Of course, this is a dynamic<br>

king it real "competitive coevolution", of course a record of<br>=

uring who won is not a<br>

&g=
t; > I still think novelty search brings a lot of benefits to the table.=
 My<br>

 population growth<br>

emains the hosts until their population has grown the specified<br>

t; amount. I'm hoping that will encourage a nice broad range of strateg=

 a "cataclysmic event"<br>

ure-neat? Harold Camping-neat?)  to wipe out the<br>

tion, and only the best performing hosts are kept, which would<br>

; be how it integrates into the competition side of things. .<br>

sed to explore<br>

vent, then performance is used<br>

own, and give the "other team" their go.<br>
